description: New OpenVPN platform information 'IV_PLAT=linux' logged; could be indicative of VPN enumeration or fingerprinting.
Unusually long and high-entropy DNS query suggests DNS tunneling, possibly for exfiltrating a file.
Query to domain with anomalous entropy; may be used for covert communication or C2 over DNS.
DNS query from internal IP (10.35.33.116) to known Ubuntu resource; could indicate a new device or lateral movement.
Audit log shows start of grub-common via systemd with root UID; uncommon for runtime grub use, may indicate bootloader tampering.
Audit log shows stopping of grub-common; similar context to previous start log, unusual service activity.
Slight increase in normalized CPU usage detected; while marginal, persistent shifts may indicate resource hijacking attempts.
Syslog indicates successful GRUB boot recording; in context with other grub activity, may indicate bootloader persistence.
Referer URL contains internal subdomain with suspicious structure; may suggest internal phishing or reconnaissance.
Referer with uncommon characters detected in web access log; may indicate crafted URL for scanning or fingerprinting.
A new IP address (192.168.131.234) queried motd.ubuntu.com, which may indicate a new host beaconing or bootstrapping over DNS.
Spike in A-record DNS queries may indicate beaconing behavior or dynamic DNS usage by malware.
High frequency of HTTP GET requests to root path from uncommon client suggests web scanning or automated probing.
High volume of DNS queries from multiple internal IPs, especially to security domains, may indicate network discovery or data staging.
PTR query for reverse DNS lookup suggests host or service enumeration by an internal IP.
A single DNS A-record query to a known update server (motd.ubuntu.com) is normal OS behavior.
Unusual AAAA (IPv6) query to internal domain may suggest covert communication or misconfigured service.
TXT query to clamav.net may be a signature update, but could also be used for C2 over DNS.
Repeated AAAA DNS queries to internal host by the same IP is indicative of beaconing or persistence mechanism testing.
Elevated frequency of DNS queries from 192.168.128.195 indicates possible beaconing or automated data exfiltration.
Unusual frequency of PTR DNS queries from internal IP 192.168.128.195 suggests possible DNS tunneling for data exfiltration or command and control.
TLS key negotiation failure in OpenVPN may indicate an attacker attempting to disrupt VPN connections or brute-force credentials.
Repeated TLS handshake failures can indicate a brute-force or misconfigured client trying to access VPN infrastructure.
Session move with reinit_src=1 suggests possible attempt to hijack or reset an active TLS VPN session.
Second instance of TLS key negotiation failure indicates persistence or automation in attack or faulty VPN config.
Repeated TLS handshake failures could indicate scanning or brute-force against OpenVPN.
Third occurrence of TLS negotiation timeout suggests active probing or denial strategy.
Persistent TLS handshake failures imply a sustained attempt to access VPN using invalid or brute-forced credentials.
Use of uncommon characters in PROPFIND HTTP method to interact with WebDAV endpoint implies probing or enumeration of shared files.
Unusual characters in GET request for file storage stats suggest enumeration or information gathering using WebDAV interface.
Suspicious characters '(', ')' in URL referer parameter, possibly used to test server behavior or inject path traversal/local file access requests.
Deprecated PHP constructor warning with a non-standard referer suggests automated vulnerability scanning or misconfigured application accessing legacy PHP classes.
Slight frequency increase in TXT DNS queries may suggest use of DNS for covert C2 communication (e.g., DNS tunneling or TXT-based beaconing).
Sustained abnormal TXT query frequency reinforces likelihood of DNS-based communication channel, possibly used for beaconing or data exchange.
High entropy domain (i.li.ru) in DNS query indicates potential use of algorithmically generated domains (DGAs) or fast-flux infrastructure for C2.
Excessively long and complex domain with structured filename hints at encoded exfiltrated data or DGA-based domain used in DNS tunneling.
High frequency of queries from many internal IPs to anomalous DNS domain suggests potential coordinated beaconing or exfiltration attempts.
New ssh login audit event for unknown user 'hwarren' indicates a potentially newly created or compromised account used over SSH.
New user 'jessica.wright' authenticated via dovecot; potential sign of newly added or compromised user account being used for email access.
Request to WordPress admin script with uncommon characters (e.g., ',' in parameter list) may indicate plugin enumeration or probing for vulnerabilities.
DNS query contains a long, obfuscated string resembling data exfiltration or command-and-control via DNS tunneling.
Authentication event with a new combination of parameters for a privileged account using Dovecot authentication service.
Query for 'ipv4only.arpa' is part of RFC 8880 for NAT64 discovery and not malicious.
Repeated query for 'ipv4only.arpa' domain, which is expected in dual-stack networks using NAT64.
Forwarded query for 'ipv4only.arpa', commonly used by clients for DNS64 NAT detection.
Redundant 'ipv4only.arpa' query, likely part of a legitimate operating system DNS behavior.
Another repeated 'ipv4only.arpa' query used for NAT64/DNS64 mechanism validation.
Same as previous 'ipv4only.arpa' queries; legitimate usage by system resolver.
Normal DNS reply resolving a hostname to IP; entropy score is misleading.
Unusual HTTP method (REPORT) combined with WebDAV access over HTTPS, possibly for C2 or file exfiltration.
Unseen internal IP making DNS request to location.services.mozilla.com; potential indicator of beaconing behavior.
New sudo credential refresh combination for root user; may indicate privilege escalation or lateral movement setup.
New sudo session start as root; unusual user_start activity linked to elevated privilege.
New sudo session end for root; consistent with elevated activity in prior events.
New credential disposal (setcred) pattern for root; may be part of a credential manipulation process.
New characters in suspicious PHP GET request with long token-like parameters; likely probing or exploitation attempt.
Unusual characters in HTTP referer to a PHP script; possibly part of phishing or scripted access.
Authentication to dovecot service using new user (meghan.morris); possibly a newly compromised account.
New user account activity in dovecot service log; may relate to account misuse or lateral movement.
New request path in web service using AJAX endpoint; could indicate probing or enum via web API.
The request to `/services/ajax.php/kronolith/listEvents` contains new characters indicating previously unseen request patterns, potentially probing a web calendar plugin.
High entropy in DNS domain `cdn.ampproject.org` suggests obfuscated or algorithmically generated domain use, possibly for evasion.
Duplicate high-entropy domain alert for `cdn.ampproject.org`, likely benign due to legitimate use by Google AMP.
New IP `192.168.130.19` making DNS queries may indicate a new host or lateral movement/reconnaissance within internal network.
New internal IP `172.17.128.63` querying DNS for Ubuntu MOTD suggests a newly active or deployed system.
New IP `10.35.32.78` issuing DNS queries. Likely benign (e.g., boot-up query), unless corroborated by other anomalies.
Referer includes new characters like `=`, `?`, and numeric values indicating parameter probing.
Request URI contains a plugin path with unfamiliar character `z`, suggesting plugin enumeration or exploitation attempts.
Referer includes suspicious plugin-related query strings, indicating plugin fingerprinting via CSS/font requests.
Referer includes new numeric characters possibly tied to plugin versioning, suggesting version enumeration of WordPress plugin.
Suspicious POST request to a known vulnerable endpoint (/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php) with unexpected character 'x' in the request. This could be probing or exploitation of a WordPress plugin.
DNS query to a high-entropy domain (taylorcruz-mail) indicating potential use of DNS for C2 communication or data exfiltration.
Abnormal spike in frequency of AAAA DNS queries, potentially indicative of automated DNS-based beaconing.
Repeated DNS query to a high-entropy domain, similar to earlier alert, reinforcing suspicion of DNS tunneling.
New combination of parameters in systemd audit logs for 'apt-daily-upgrade' startup could indicate attacker persistence via scheduled service modification.
New combination of parameters in systemd audit logs for 'apt-daily-upgrade' shutdown may be part of persistent service evasion or clean-up mechanism.
Query to 'ocsp.pki.goog' is a normal OCSP certificate check for HTTPS validation and the entropy threshold is set too low.
Forwarding of 'ocsp.pki.goog' to 8.8.8.8 (Google DNS) is expected behavior in most HTTPS traffic using Google's PKI.
AAAA query for 'ocsp.pki.goog' is standard for clients requesting IPv6 OCSP responses.
Repetition of OCSP domain forwarded againâ€”likely part of normal validation retry, not indicative of malicious behavior.
High entropy DNS request to ocsp.pki.goog may indicate domain fronting or DNS tunneling used for C2 communication.
Repeated high-entropy DNS domain response for ocsp.pki.goog, which may indicate suspicious tunneling or domain fronting, but likely benign as it relates to Google's OCSP infrastructure.
Unusual DNS query pattern detected (AAAA query for internal mail name), which may indicate internal reconnaissance or enumeration.
DNS request to motd.ubuntu.com is related to update checks, but frequency anomaly suggests potential misuse or spoofing.
Frequency anomaly for DNS queries to internal mail resource, possible lateral movement or enumeration activity.
Repeated unusual DNS queries to internal mail resource, consistent with host discovery or asset scanning.
TXT DNS query to ClamAV update server from local host shows low frequency anomaly; could be benign or attacker spoofing known services.
Horde webmail unauthorized access attempt detected for user megan.johnson; suggests credential abuse or brute-force attempt.
Unusual DNS query to mail.dmz.price.fox.org suggests either beaconing to internal server or internal lateral discovery.
Anomalous spike in CPU usage by system agent, possibly due to crypto-mining or unauthorized heavy computation tasks.
Unusual frequency of DNS queries to uncommon IPs from internal hosts may indicate data exfiltration or beaconing over DNS.
Special characters in file download URL using uncommon user agent suggest automated or crafted request possibly exploiting file download function.
Repeat of suspicious file download with special characters in request indicates automated exploitation attempt across multiple IPs.
Sudden increase in normalized CPU usage could indicate background unauthorized computation such as cryptomining.
High frequency of reverse DNS lookups (PTR queries) can indicate network reconnaissance or C2 beaconing activity.
Repeated web access using complex download request with suspicious encoding and user-agent suggests automated probing or exploitation.
Same pattern of suspicious web request as earlier, coming from a different internal IP, suggesting scripted attack or vulnerability scan.
DNS AAAA query for likely internal system name 'jonesmorgan-mail' suggests host discovery or subdomain enumeration.
Repeated query for the same internal domain name within short interval increases confidence of DNS-based reconnaissance.
Unusual frequency of DNS queries detected, specifically AAAA query for a potentially suspicious domain ('taylorcruz-mail') from an internal IP. This can indicate data exfiltration or C2 via DNS.
